messageBody:
Glad you found us.

I live in Indiana and am in my early 60s.  I always make the distinction between Why and Way and always have.  That is my natural pronunciation, but I know that I am in the minority now in the U.S.  I have five brothers and I am the eldest.  The brother born after me also pronounces Why.  The other three do not, and we were all raised in the same family.  It seems very curious to me for this difference in speech to exist over such a short period of time.

I suspect that you think of the "h" in the digraph "wh" as a silent letter.  I recently heard of an elementary teacher, who, no doubt, shared your lack of Why in her idiolect, and she taught her students that the "h" was silent.  I was stunned because it was clear that she viewed her idiolect as "normal" and did not realize that a significant percentage of the U.S. population still pronounces the "h."

I use the Why symbol because I pronounce it.  Those who don't pronounce it, presumably don't use the symbol.  It does not cause any difficulty in reading in my opinion.

I also make the distinction between Awe-Ah-Ox.  When I hear someone pronounce "nautical" as if it were spelled "notical" it seems very peculiar to me.  How do you pronounce the word "Awe"?  Does it just sound like the vowel in "on"?

Good luck in your QS studies.  I hope the site is useful to you and that you make good progress.  Remember, practice makes perfect.

Paige Gabhart


On 11/15/2010 11:37 PM, leaves_or wrote:
 

I sought out this group because I was having a hard time distinguishing Awe-Ah-Ox. It's gratifying to see that I'm not the only one with that problem. (I'm California-born and Seattle-raised, so no wonder).

I have a similar problem distinguishing Why from Way. Is this also characteristic of the western USA? Is the letter combination "wh" always written with Why? Are there any other cases that you would use it? For me, "wine" and "whine" or "weather" and "whether" are homophones.

Since I'm learning Quickscript for personal use, it doesn't make much difference, I was just curious.

Lauren
